Home / Case Studies / Xpress Weigh

Empowering Consultants to support members on their weight-loss journey.

  • Slimming World
  • 2025

A multi-phase project to redesign Slimming World‚Äôs flagship member support tool from the ground up.

The first phase focused on a rapid redesign of the existing screens, improving usability while working within the constraints of the existing technology.

The second phase was part of a broader transformation of the platform, developing the same area from scratch as part of a redefined product ecosystem.

Role

  • Immersive longitudinal research
  • Stakeholder management
  • Design & prototyping
  • Moderated usability testing
  • Developer liaison

TL;DR

Phase 1

Problem

‘Xpress Weigh’ is a legacy suite of tools used by Consultants to run weekly member groups. The software runs on Windows tablets and supports enrolment, payments, weight recording, and access to member data during live sessions.

Accumulated technical and design debt left the system difficult to use and maintain, and misaligned with the goals of group delivery. As Slimming World began exploring wider digital transformation, the member support experience came under particular scrutiny. Complex, cluttered screens were acting as a barrier to the essential human connection that is at the heart of the group.

I was tasked with delivering targeted, interim usability improvements, with a specific focus on reducing friction and protecting the human connection that underpins a successful group experience.

Exisiting solution: Two complex screens were a barrier to natural, supportive member conversations.

Approach

Years of embedded ethnographic exposure ‚Äî participating in groups as both a member and assistant ‚Äî provided a grounded understanding of real-world use. Targeted one-to-one research interviews with Consultants across experience levels validated and sharpened those insights.

The findings were consistent: live sessions were slowed by hunt-and-peck navigation, most available data went untouched, and workarounds had become normalised. The problem wasn‚Äôt capability ‚Äî it was excess and friction in a high-tempo environment.

In close collaboration with the Directors of Field and Training, I led a reframing of the tool around essential actions and essential data. We removed peripheral information, reduced cognitive load, and designed for standing, in-group use.

The outcome was a streamlined interface built around single-click input and faster information retrieval ‚Äî a system that supports Consultants in the moment, rather than competing for their attention.

  • The resulting design is cleaner and more accessible while remaining consistent with the wider application.
  • Key data points are prioritised visually and optimised for quick glancing.
  • Data entry happens in context rather than in a separate screen.
  • Previous/next navigation spans almost the full height of the screen, designed around the ergonomics of holding and operating a tablet while standing.

Impact

I rapidly produced, usability tested, and iterated ‚Äî removing the risk of costly changes during development.

Released as an optional setting (‘classic’ or ‘new’), the redesign saw >90% uptake within the first six weeks ‚Äî despite a typically change-resistant audience.

Site visit data confirmed a clear uplift in Quality of Service following implementation

Phase 2

Building on success

As Slimming World embarked on a full digital transformation, I was tasked with leading the redesign of the full suite of tools used to support the Consulatnts across all aspects of running their business.

My Consultant ecosystem map indicates the scale and scope of my role in the business' digital transformation.
The red circle highlights the subject of this article.

Problem

The member-support screens came back into focus at executive level, with broader stakeholder involvement and a strong appetite for transformation.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not changing the group process.‚Äù

While there was a transformational mindset around the technology, group procedure was considered sacrosanct. The platform could change; the live group experience could not.

An early part of my role was making this distinction clear: the technology was subservient to the group process. Its job was to support a 50-year-old operating model ‚Äî not compete with or redefine it.

Tap to view full map

I mapped two years of the Consultant lifecycle as an anchor for the wider ecosystem redevelopment. This served multiple projects and products, and was helpfed to bring clarity to what belonged in group and what happened outside.

Approach

The user journey map created a shared view of the end-to-end process and became a reference point in conversations about what data truly belonged on screen. For example, extensive historical data, while valuable for context, was repositioned into preparation and reporting workflows.

Working directly with the board and senior stakeholders, I defined the tool in detail ‚Äî down to what appeared on screen and how it needed to perform under real-time pressure. Through workshops, co-design sessions and a buy-your-data prioritisation exercise with senior consultants and the company owner, we clarified what stayed visible, what got cut, and made explicit trade-offs to ensure each data point earned its place.

I also organised service safaris with product and engineering colleagues to build shared understanding of the live group environment. A Six Thinking Hats session tested the approach against operational and technical realities, refining it for practical use.

“…the information for stage one needs to smack you in the face”
- Director of the Field

The quote became a shared shorthand across co-design sessions ‚Äî referenced when clarity was at risk.

Outcome

Through structured critique and repeated refinement, I defined:

  • A clear on-screen information hierarchy
  • Simplified visibility rules
  • Agreed principles for how data should surface during the live session

The result was a coherent, board-aligned design direction supported by sophisticated Figma prototypes, and validated with hallway usability tests.

I was ready for full stress testing in a simulated group environment üéâüéâ

The very first designs were stripped right back to basics, ensuring any additions had to be discussed and justified in conversation with stakeholders.

Whilst complexity inevtably grew, it was through measured conversation and validated user needs.

Figma variables and variable collections allowed me to create sophisitcated prototypes with customisable content, display, and weight units (metric/imperial).

After multiple rounds of iteration and refinement with the business leaders, I was ready to move to a simulated group environment for full usability testing.

images
‚ÄúWe're not changing the group process.‚Äù “We are changing the group process.”

A slight pivot

As the iterative design phase concluded, the company went on to make a methodological shift. The Consultant‚Äôs role moved from structured, one-to-one support, to a more facilitative member-led format.

To fully understand the implications of this, I observed the roll-out training and attended a number of groups to see how the new format was landing in practice.

It was clear the tool needed to evolve to support a different group dynamic. Rather than defending earlier work, I returned to the principles we had defined and evolved the interaction model to suit the new group dynamic.

I introduced an index layer in front of the existing screens ‚Äî a stripped-back, in-the-moment summary of all members ‚Äî while preserving immediate access to the richer data set carefully defined through research and prioritisation.

I designed a new index to improve scan and findability during live sessions, supported by a hub-and-spoke navigation model that reflected the new group format and enabled occasional, non-linear access to member data.

Advanced prototyping

Having devleoped and iterated the index screen in Figma, I took the opportunity to quickly rebuild the full prototype in Figma Make. The prompt-and-code approach allowed me to rapidly create realistic data sets that more closely mimiced a live applicatio - using event listeners and maintaing state across numerous data sets in ways that would be all-but impossible using standard Figma features.

Rebuilding the prototype in Figma Make allowed for robust data set and richer interactivity.

Stress testing

I organised and ran immersive usability testing, simulating the group envionment and having colleagues from across design, product, engineering, in addition to senior stakeholders, play th part of group members.

Real Consultants were able to use the prototypes on tablet devices under observation, and feeding back to inform iteration.

Following serval roudns of testing, the product signed off and ready to move into development.

Rebuilding the prototype in Figma Make allowed for robust data set and richer interactivity.

Impact & reflections

This was a challenging project for a number of reasons, not least of which the emotional attachment felt at the highest levels of the business coupled with a change of direction mid-way through.

Thgeorugh consistent stakeholder collaboration and user research, I was able to successfully design an early beta that played a notable part in qulity of service improvments, and navigate a path through numerous iterations, conflicting opinions and the business leads inherent urge to take a kitchen sink approach, to poduce a design that was test and proven, derisking development.

Based in London.

Designing product experiences that feel inevitable.
